awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Enabling Long-Term Security and Privacy through Retrospective Data Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Online data storage, everything from past conversations to tax returns to playdate invitations, may be retained at full fidelity for years or decades. Although the data being saved in online archives does not change, the personal and social contexts surrounding them do. Those life changes may necessitate changing or deleting stored data but, unfortunately, the vast quantity of data in users' online archives makes manual management infeasible. The goal of this project is to develop methods and tools that enable users to manage the data they have accumulated over many years, leveraging user-centered design and machine learning to partially automate the process. These tools will enable a better understanding of retrospective privacy in the context of modern long-lived online archives. They will also empower users to more effectively manage the risks embedded in these archives. The findings shared with the research community will advance discovery beyond this project. 

The understanding of user conceptualizations of security and privacy over time, as contexts change, has been stymied by a lack of broad, carefully collected datasets within this domain. This project will collect anonymized datasets, with users' permission, that enable further research in this area. The team is conducting one of the first longitudinal studies of how desired security and privacy decisions change over time. The project will also gather qualitative insights about users' perceptions of risk and utility for long-term data, as well as the acceptability of retrospective management mechanisms. Furthermore, it is not currently understood how temporality impacts the use of machine learning techniques for privacy, nor how to capture concept drift to ensure that latent threats can be identified within immense archives. These tasks require new machine learning approaches and predictive models that can both account for the temporal dimension and minimize user burden when automating archive management. Finally, the project will design and implement novel user-centered interfaces that address the currently unmet need of helping users efficiently minimize security and privacy risks in their large, long-term online archives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Popular digital services have been integral to modern life for decades, causing many consumers to accumulate unnecessary data. Unfortunately, some of this forgotten data poses security and privacy risks. Although users should periodically reevaluate whether to retain stored data, the sheer size of online archives makes manual management impractical. This project developed novel, user-centered technologies to help users revisit past privacy and security decisions in two key domains: cloud file storage and social media.

In the cloud storage domain, researchers conducted pioneering studies on what types of cloud-stored data consumers perceive as sensitive. Through direct engagement with participants, the project developed a clearer characterization of forgotten files deemed both sensitive and useless. This characterization informed the creation of novel machine learning classifiers capable of automatically identifying such data. These classifiers outperformed existing approaches and baselines for detecting sensitive, redundant, or obsolete files. Additionally, the project improved understanding of how consumers perceive similarities among their cloud-stored data, enabling the development of recommendation techniques based on users' previous file management actions.

To translate these insights into practice, the project designed, implemented, and evaluated multiple new user interfaces to present classifier recommendations. The interfaces included methods for grouping related recommendations to enhance user comprehension and decision-making. Additionally, the project refined these interfaces into a fully functional web application built with state-of-the-art security protections. This application allows users to leverage the classifiers and supports further research through a secure platform, fostering continued innovation in cloud storage protection.

In the social media domain, researchers collected a retrospective dataset comparing users' intended privacy settings for past social media posts with the actual settings in effect. This analysis enabled the development of new classifiers to identify posts with privacy settings that might not align with users' intentions. The project also introduced a novel taxonomy of interface affordances for modifying past social media posts, accompanied by a user study to explore participants' perceptions of these affordances.

Beyond its broader impacts on cloud storage and social media privacy, the project had significant broader educational impact. It provided rigorous research and software engineering training to numerous Ph.D., master's, and undergraduate students. Many of these students pursued careers at U.S. companies and academic institutions, extending the project's positive impact into industry and academia.


Last Modified: 02/14/2025
Modified by: Christopher Kanich
